result.execSummary:
The defendant Rachel A Belanger was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Retail Theft - Intentionally Take >$500 - $5000) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.50(1m)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.  
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription.
  Use one (1) pharmacy to obtain prescriptions and disclose to agent and sign releases so agent can monitor prescription drug use and have access to pharmacy drug records and treating physician to determine compliance. Disclose any prescriptions prescribed to agent immediately.
Engage and comply in any other counseling reasonably related to the offense as recommended by the Agent.
Submit DNA sample, if not already done so.
Pay cost and DNA surcharge.
No jail credit.
No restitution requested.
Obtain and maintain full-time employment or schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time.

records.addlTxt:
from DOC dated 12-27-2018 request for correction of credit
   /s/ RJS - approval of 1 additional day of incarceration credit
Transcript of Sentencing Hearing on Revocation held on September 28, 2018

Defendant Rachel A Belanger in court and in custody with Attorney (Atty) William George Weiland. Prosecuting Assistant District Attorney (ADA) Louis John Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Parties have received and reviewed the Revocation Warrant packet. Parties agree on 233 days credit and recommend a prison sentence. 
BY THE COURT: 
Determinate Prison Sentence
 18 months Incarceration and  2 yrs Extended Supervision, eligible for both Challenge and Substance abuse programs. 233 days credit. 
Balance of court costs and surcharges are to be converted to civil judgment.

Written Determinate form is completed.
Appeal rights provided.
Sentencing Hearing on Revocation set for 09/28/18 - not deliverable as addressed
Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosequendum with attached Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosequendum /s/ RJS 09/05/18

records.addlTxt:
11:33 a.m. Defendant Rachel A Belanger in court with attorney Anne Renc. Defendant Rachel A Belanger in custody. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement. Request for Count 2: W/H Sentence 3 yrs Probation w/conditions.
Attorney for Defendant concurs with agreement stated.

Defendant enters a plea of: Count 2 - No Contest

Court questions Defendant regarding plea.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney for Defendant.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charge(s).

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charge(s).
Court finds the defendant guilty Count 2.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date. Count 1 is dismissed and read in.

ADA Constable requests joint recommendation to be adopted. 
Atty Renc concurs and request probation to transfer to Rock County.
Defendant makes apologetic statements.

BY THE COURT:****PROBATION****
Count 2: 943.50(1)(b) Retail Theft-repeater - felony
W/H Sentence: 3 yrs Probation
Conditions:
 AODA & comply with treatment recommendations.  
Do not possess or consume alcohol or be on premises where alcohol is served/sold as its primary business except within scope of your employment.  
Do not possess/consume controlled substances without a valid prescription and be taken according to the prescription.
  Use one (1) pharmacy to obtain prescriptions and disclose to agent and sign releases so agent can monitor prescription drug use and have access to pharmacy drug records and treating physician to determine compliance. Disclose any prescriptions prescribed to agent immediately.
  Obtain and maintain full-time employment or schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time.
  Engage and comply in any other counseling reasonably related to the offense as recommended by the Agent.
  Submit DNA sample, if not already done so.
Pay cost and DNA surcharge.
No jail credit.
No restitution requested.
/s/ RJS 02/02/16 with attached Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosquendum

Pre-trial conference at 02-01-2016 10:30 am

Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions the Defendant regarding Waiver of Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 

Arraignment:
  State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

NOT GUILTY Plea(s) entered.

Bond Continued.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for February 1, 2016 at 10:30 am.

Attorney Anne Renc in court. Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant Rachel A Belanger appeared by video. Prosecuting Atty Elizabeth R. Constable appeared for State of Wisconsin.    Defendant/Attorney received copy of Criminal Complaint and waived its reading.
Court informs Defendant of Charges and maximum penalties.
Bond continued.  Preliminary hearing scheduled for December 21, 2015 at 03:00 pm.

Defendant appears from jail by video.
Defendant indicates that she will be eligible for a Public Defender.
ADA Constable states facts for anticipated charges of Bail Jumping - Felony, Bail Jumping - Misdemeanor, Retail Theft 
Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.
Court informs Defendant right to an attorney and/or Public Defender.
Court questions Defendant. 
State requests a signature bond of $1,500.00 with conditions as stated.
